items.synopsis: Charlie Teo was fighting two complaints of unprofessional conduct from the families of two different women, who say they were not properly warned about the risk of death before consenting to surgery.

image.altText: An older man with greying light hair and glasses wearing a suit and tie stands in front of a blue Reserve Bank of Australia wall

items.synopsis: Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe announces big changes to RBA board, including fewer board meetings a year, and press conferences after every meeting.

title.children: Reserve Bank board to only meet eight times a year as part of big changes, says governor Philip Lowe

image.altText: An image of the Reserve bank sign in Martin Place, Sydney

items.synopsis: RBA governor Philip Lowe is speaking in Brisbane where he's expected to discuss changes to the bank's structure and reasons for pausing its current rate hiking cycle last week. Follow live.

title.children: RBA governor reveals changes to bank's structure and reasons for rate pause

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A final question to Lowe came from Mackenzie Scott from The Australian, who asked whether high migration was impacting rising house prices and rents, and therefore having an impact on interest rates needing to keep rising. Here's how he answered: "It is not having a direct influence  but through a couple of channels the fact that there are a lot more  people coming into the country has eased pressures and some labour  markets, particularly, in the  hospitality sector because a lot of the increase in population over six months has been students. They often work in hospitality sector. "Our  liaison with firms in that sector  say it is easy to get workers and  has taken some of the heat out of  that labour market. That works in  the short term to put inflation  down, on the other hand, all these people coming in have to live  somewhere. "That is pushing up rents and housing prices and with your  housing prices would continue to  decline this year but they are not. In Sydney, the rising quite strongly again. And that is partly to the  influx of immigration. "There are  pluses and minuses in terms of  inflation outlook. Helping contain wages growth that [is] putting upward pressure on  rates. But we talk about it and the bank, if we're going to have a lot more people the country, which is  good, we need the capital stock to support those people. "Otherwise the capital-labour ratio declines and  that is bad for productivity, so  population growth brings huge  advantages to the contrary but we  need governments and businesses to keep investing to build a capital  stock to support a stronger  population. "The housing market is  the clearest example of that but  there are a lot of other examples as well. "It is a broader issue than  just the short-term inflation  outlook it is how we build the  capital stock to support a larger or diverse population which I think is in long-term interest."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is migration and rising house and rent prices keeping interest rates high?

children.content: A final question to Lowe came from Mackenzie Scott from The Australian, who asked whether high migration was impacting rising house prices and rents, and therefore having an impact on interest rates needing to keep rising.
Here's how he answered:

"It is not having a direct influence  but through a couple of channels the fact that there are a lot more  people coming into the country has eased pressures and some labour  markets, particularly, in the  hospitality sector because a lot of the increase in population over six months has been students. They often work in hospitality sector.

"Our  liaison with firms in that sector  say it is easy to get workers and  has taken some of the heat out of  that labour market. That works in  the short term to put inflation  down, on the other hand, all these people coming in have to live  somewhere.

"That is pushing up rents and housing prices and with your  housing prices would continue to  decline this year but they are not. In Sydney, the rising quite strongly again. And that is partly to the  influx of immigration.

"There are  pluses and minuses in terms of  inflation outlook. Helping contain wages growth that [is] putting upward pressure on  rates. But we talk about it and the bank, if we're going to have a lot more people the country, which is  good, we need the capital stock to support those people.

"Otherwise the capital-labour ratio declines and  that is bad for productivity, so  population growth brings huge  advantages to the contrary but we  need governments and businesses to keep investing to build a capital  stock to support a stronger  population.
"The housing market is  the clearest example of that but  there are a lot of other examples as well.
"It is a broader issue than  just the short-term inflation  outlook it is how we build the  capital stock to support a larger or diverse population which I think is in long-term interest."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A reporter from Bloomberg has asked the RBA governor whether he is more confident now that interest rate increases are having an impact, compared to two months ago. Here's his reply: "I am  confident that higher interest rates are working. Talk to any retailer at the moment they will say I'm  spending slowly and people trading down to cheaper items and in some  cases small baskets. "Consumption  growth is weak and that is largely because of what is going on with  monetary policy but also the  declining incomes from higher  inflation [shows the] policy is working, the  issue is do we have to do more? "And as I said in my remarks that is to be determined and will be determined by our assessment of the inflation risks and outlook on what is going on with spending. "We're confident  what we're doing working, the  question mark is what do we need to do and we have a completely open  mind on that question."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is the RBA confident its rate rises are working?

children.content: A reporter from Bloomberg has asked the RBA governor whether he is more confident now that interest rate increases are having an impact, compared to two months ago.
Here's his reply:

"I am  confident that higher interest rates are working. Talk to any retailer at the moment they will say I'm  spending slowly and people trading down to cheaper items and in some  cases small baskets.

"Consumption  growth is weak and that is largely because of what is going on with  monetary policy but also the  declining incomes from higher  inflation [shows the] policy is working, the  issue is do we have to do more?
"And as I said in my remarks that is to be determined and will be determined by our assessment of the inflation risks and outlook on what is going on with spending.
"We're confident  what we're doing working, the  question mark is what do we need to do and we have a completely open  mind on that question."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's a question from our colleague, the ABC's very own Michael Janda! He's asking about the removal of the mortgage serviceability test, and whether that's increased risks in the economy. (If you'll allow me, it's a very good question.) Here's Lowe's response: "My memory is not good  enough to remember the specifics but we have recently been talking about the 3 per cent interest serviceability  buffer I think that is the right  size of the buffer because it picks up not just interest rate risk but other risk borrowers have. "This has not been a major topic of discussion over recent times. I think the macro credential in Australia by and large have been successful. "There are  restrictions on interest only loans and investor loans. Almost half of the loan has been made in Australia were interest only and limited to  investors and was assigned the  excesses and that together we  thought it was right thing, a 3 per cent serviceability and buffer on mortgages was the right thing. "That  relationship between RBA has worked very well and the Government has  been constructive."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Was removing the mortgage serviceability test detrimental to the economy?

children.content: Here's a question from our colleague, the ABC's very own Michael Janda!
He's asking about the removal of the mortgage serviceability test, and whether that's increased risks in the economy.
(If you'll allow me, it's a very good question.)
Here's Lowe's response:

"My memory is not good  enough to remember the specifics but we have recently been talking about the 3 per cent interest serviceability  buffer I think that is the right  size of the buffer because it picks up not just interest rate risk but other risk borrowers have.
"This has not been a major topic of discussion over recent times. I think the macro credential in Australia by and large have been successful.

"There are  restrictions on interest only loans and investor loans. Almost half of the loan has been made in Australia were interest only and limited to  investors and was assigned the  excesses and that together we  thought it was right thing,
a 3 per cent serviceability and buffer on mortgages was the right thing.
"That  relationship between RBA has worked very well and the Government has  been constructive."
